brief_description of the content in the: The source URL provides information about a potential issue in Quarkus applications where endpoint methods might not have the @Produces or @Consumes annotations. Quarkus uses these annotations to minimize the number of JAX-RS providers included in the native executable, thereby reducing its size. The page suggests annotating methods or the entire class with @Produces or @Consumes and specifying the target MIME types.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'undeclared_path_mime_types_inspection' checks all classes and their methods in the application. If a method has the '@Path' annotation, the rule asserts that it should also have either the '@Produces' or '@Consumes' annotation. If this is not the case, it generates a message indicating the method and class that violate this rule.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. URL: https://quarkus.io/guides/rest-json - This guide from the official Quarkus website provides information on how to use JAX-RS, JSON-B, and RESTEasy to create RESTful web services. It emphasizes the importance of using @Produces and @Consumes annotations to specify the MIME types that a method can consume and produce.

2. URL: https://www.baeldung.com/jax-rs-response - This article on Baeldung explains how to use JAX-RS to build RESTful web services in Java. It discusses the use of @Path, @Produces, and @Consumes annotations in defining the endpoints.
